turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Menerba.
turn.1: What hot flashes were studied in relation to Menerba?
turn.2: In 2007, Menerba completed a multi-center Phase 2, double-blind, placebo-controlled randomized clinical trial evaluating its potential for the treatment of hot flashes in 217 healthy post-menopausal women in the U.S. The principal investigator of the trial was Dr. Deborah Grady from the University of California, San Francisco.
turn.3: Did the clinical trial show that Menerba was an effective treatment for hot flashes?
turn.4: Menerba showed a statistically significant reduction in the number of hot flashes after 12 weeks of treatment and had a statistically significant reduction in nighttime awakenings from hot flashes (-67%, p=0.05).
turn.5: Did Menerba have any side effects?
turn.6: There was no difference in uterine bleeding between treatment groups and placebo, and no uterine abnormalities were observed during the study.
turn.7: What other side effects were studied?
turn.8: The only side effect observed was mild loose stools (12% in treatment group vs.
turn.11: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.12: Further studies have shown that most active estrogenic compound in Menerba is liquiritigenin, derived from the root of "Glycyrrhizae uralensis" Fisch, one of the 22 botanically derived ingredients found in Menerba.
